Text: Trump says no deal but 'progress made' after Ukraine talks with Putin "We didn't get there," the US president says in a statement to the press after a "productive" three-hour meeting with Putin.
Summarized_Data: – President Trump called his meeting with Vladimir Putin a "10 out of 10" in a pre-recorded interview with Sean Hannity of Fox News, which is due to air a few minutes. Trump also praises Putin for agreeing that if he was president at the time Russia invaded Ukraine war "would have never happened." Trump is asked to grade the meeting with Putin this afternoon, Trump says he always had a great relationship with President Putin. He adds that now it's up to Zelensky to get a deal done, along with European involvement. He says that Russia and Ukraine will set up talks next, with both Putin and Zelensky attending. Trump is asked how he thinks the war in Ukraine might end - with land swaps? These points were negotiated during the meeting with Putin, Trump says, and were "largely" agreed on. But, Trump says, Ukraine has to agree to any deal. He suggests there is movement towards a potential prisoner of war transfer. Trump is asked to grade the meeting with President Putin. He says it was a "10 out of 10", adding: "We got along great." He adds that now it's up to Zelensky to get a deal done, along with European involvement. He says that Russia and Ukraine will set up talks next, with both Putin and Zelensky attending.

Text: No ceasefire, no deal. What summit means for Trump, Putin and Ukraine Three BBC correspondents at the meeting in Alaska assess what we learned about the two leaders and what's next for the war.
Summarized_Data: – It was a roundabout way of conceding that after several hours of talks, there's no deal. No ceasefire. Nothing tangible to report.The president said that he and Vladimir Putin made "some great progress", but with little details about what that might be, it's left to the world's imagination.Trump traveled a long way to only produce such vagaries, even if America's European allies and Ukrainian officials may be relieved he did not offer unilateral concessions or agreements that could have undermined future negotiations.The big question now—one reporters were unable to ask on Friday—is whether Trump will decide to impose his much-threatened new sanctions on Russia as punishment or if he will find a reason to once again push the deadlines farther down the road.The president said that he and Vladimir Putin made "some great progress", but with little details about what that might be, it's left to the world's imagination.Trump traveled a long way to only produce such vagaries, even if America's European allies and Ukrainian officials may be relieved he did not offer unilateral concessions or agreements that could have undermined future negotiations.The big question now—one reporters were unable to ask on Friday—is whether Trump will decide to impose his much-threatened new sanctions on Russia as punishment or if he will find a reason to once again push the deadlines farther down the road.

Text: Watch: How the Trump-Putin summit unfolded in 82 seconds The meeting concluded with no deal being reached between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin but "great progress" was made in Ukraine talks.
Summarized_Data: – President Trump and Vladimir Putin concluded their meeting in Alaska after a few hours of talking. The meeting ended with no deal being reached on Ukraine talks, but "great progress" was made, according to Trump. During the joint press conference, Putin said that he is "sincerely interested" in putting an end to the conflict. The BBC asked Texans and those visiting the state about US President Trump's decision to bomb three nuclear sites. Trump told Boakai he speaks "such good English", asking where he went to school.

Text: 'Next time in Moscow?' - Putin invites Trump to Russia with rare use of English Russian President Vladimir Putin invited US President Donald Trump to Moscow at the end of their joint press conference in Alaska.
Summarized_Data: – Vladimir Putin spoke in Russian for the majority of the press conference, but switched to English to invite him to Moscow. Donald Trump told Boakai he speaks "such good English", asking where he went to school. Putin spoke in Russian for the majority of the press conference, but switched to English to invite him to Moscow. The BBC asked Texans and those visiting the state about US President Trump's decision to bomb three nuclear sites.

Text: In maps: The war-ravaged Ukrainian territories at the heart of the Trump-Putin summit Kyiv has rejected ceding territory seized by Russia to secure a ceasefire.
Summarized_Data: – President Trump's meeting with Vladimir Putin on Friday in Alaska could have major implications for Ukraine. Russia has laid claim to vast parts of Ukraine since 2014, when President Vladimir Putin made his first move.At the time, in the space of a short few months, Moscow carried out the relatively bloodless occupation and annexation of the Crimean peninsula.But that was followed by a Russian-backed separatist movement in the eastern Donbas region—specifically the two regions, or "oblasts", known as Donetsk and Luhansk.A war simmered there for eight years. Ukraine lost around 14,000 soldiers and civilians during this period.As of August 2025, the territory of Ukraine looks as follows: Russia would dearly love to expand its control over the entirety of Luhansk and Donetsk.Some reports suggest that Putin is demanding that Ukraine hand over the remaining territory it controls in both oblasts.But that would mean Kyiv giving up on places which tens of thousands of Ukrainian soldiers have died trying to protect— cities like Kramatorsk and Slovyansk, and a fortified line protecting Ukrainian territory to the north and west.President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine says an unconditional ceasefire is needed now.President Trump says that is what he has been trying to achieve.But in the run-up to his Alaska summit with Putin, Trump has talked instead about territorial swaps.It is not at all clear what land Trump is referring to, or what those swaps could look like, given that all the territory in question legally belongs to Ukraine.As of August 2025, the territory of Ukraine looks as follows: Russia would dearly love to expand its control over the entirety of Luhansk and Donetsk.European allies also insist on a halt in fighting.European allies also insist on a halt in fighting.President Zelensky said on Tuesday that Ukraine "could not" leave the Donbas as Moscow would use the region as a springboard to attack the rest of the country.

Text: Handshakes and a shared limo ride: Our correspondents unpack greeting Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin appeared to have a friendly, but animated, conversation after landing in Alaska.
Summarized_Data: – The BBC asked Texans and those visiting the state about US President Trump's decision to bomb three nuclear sites. President Donald Trump is weighing whether the US will join Israel's strikes on Iran as the two Middle Eastern countries continue attacks. Donald Trump tells the BBC he is "disappointed" with Vladimir Putin over the lack of a ceasefire deal in Ukraine. The cause of the fire, which is threatening more than 800 structures and is only 7% contained, is still under investigation.

Text: Far-right Israeli minister taunts prominent Palestinian prisoner Video shows Itamar Ben Gvir telling the most prominent Palestinian prisoner Marwan Barghouti "you will not win".
Summarized_Data: – He appears aged and gaunt.Israel's national security minister, Itamar Ben Gvir, tells him: "You will not win. He who messes with the people of Israel, he who will murder our children, he who will murder our women, we will wipe him out." Marwan Barghouti, 66, was jailed by Israel more than 20 years ago after he was convicted of planning attacks that led to five civilians being killed.Opinion polls have consistently indicated that he remains the most popular Palestinian leader, and that Palestinians would vote for him in a presidential election ahead of the current Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas or Hamas leaders.He remains a senior figure in the Fatah faction, which dominates the Palestinian Authority (PA).The video originally surfaced on messaging groups for Ben Gvir's supporters on Thursday but has now been reposted on his X account.The minister says that having read how "all sorts of'senior officials'" in the PA did not like what he said, he will "repeat it again and again without apologising."Marwan Barghouti, 66, was jailed by Israel more than 20 years ago after he was convicted of planning attacks that led to five civilians being killed.His wife, Fadwa, recommended to her husband's followers that only one still be used from the video which she believed showed his strength.The head of the Palestinian Prisoners' Club, Abdullah al-Zaghari accused Israel of seeking "to eliminate him and assassinate the leaders languishing in its prisons."

Text: The US economy is a puzzle but the pieces aren't fitting together Can the world's largest economy skirt damage from tariffs?
Summarized_Data: – The US economy has slowed, growing at an annual rate of 1.2% in the first half of the year, down one percentage point from 2024. But consumer spending, despite weakening, has stayed more resilient than many had expected, despite downbeat assessments by some firms."We continue to struggle to see signs of weakness," the chief financial officer of JPMorgan Chase, America's biggest bank, told investors last month.That has raised hopes that the economy might power through, as it did a few years ago, to widespread surprise, despite getting hit with the highest inflation since the 1980s and a sharp rise in interest rates."Consumers are down but not out," wrote Michael Pearce, deputy chief US economist at Oxford Economics, which is predicting a modest recovery in spending in the months ahead, as tax cuts and a stock market recovery boost confidence.That's why there was so much focus on the producer price index, which measures wholesale prices commanded by US producers before they hit consumers, offering a clue to what's coming.That's why there was so much focus on the producer price index, which measures wholesale prices commanded by US producers before they hit consumers, offering a clue to what's coming. That has raised hopes that the economy might power through, as it did a few years ago, to widespread surprise, despite getting hit with the highest inflation since the 1980s and a sharp rise in interest rates.

Text: RFK Jr revives task force on childhood vaccine safety Children's Health Defense, an anti-vaccine group Kennedy founded, had pushed through to bring the task force back.
Summarized_Data: – The US health agency is reviving a task force on childhood vaccine safety after pressure from anti-vaccine activists to re-establish the panel. In a statement, Health and Human Services said it was reinstating the Task Force on Safer Childhood Vaccines - which was disbanded in 1998 - "to improve the safety, quality, and oversight of vaccines administered to American children." The task force will provide recommendations on childhood vaccines "that result in fewer and less serious adverse reactions than those vaccines currently on the market", the agency said. It is the latest move from Health Secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr to scrutinize the US childhood vaccine schedule. The reinstatement of the panel comes after the Children's Health Defense, an anti-vaccine group that Kennedy founded, funded a lawsuit against his administration in May for failing to re-establish the task force.
